captions.text: - I don't think it's gonna be close to
the Mexican food whatsoever.

- Yeah, it doesn't look
like a taco whatsoever.
- To me it does.
- Looks like a salad.

- A taco isn't usually in
a flour tortilla, I mean--
- [Both] It comes in corn.
(girl laughs)
- I mean, looks like your basic burrito.
Beans, rice, chicken, guacamole.
- Why is the rice white?
- I can totally eat some of these.

- I don't know if this is
mayonnaise or sour cream, but--

- Yeah, I can't even tell,
it tastes like mayonnaise.

- Why are you making our
food, you know, into this?
- The Fritos, those do give them
a little different kind of taste.
- The cheese looks like the fake cheese.
- I don't know how people think
this is good, 'cause it's not.

title: Mexican People Try Taco Bell For The First Time

comments.text:

Especially the kids.﻿
comments.author: MaplestoryMr

comments.author: Fred Rodriguez

comments.text:
Attention all Mexican people: I can say on behalf of all white people that 
we do not consider this Mexican food. Not even close. So please don't get 
all high and mighty and think that we're delusional. Taco Bell falls into a 
category all its own. Some of it is good, some of it is an abomination. 
That's like saying Burger King is "American food." It's not. Not even 
close. It's just a place that sells cheeseburgers. Open your mind a bit. 
Most of the people in this video were very close minded. ﻿

flour tortilla over power the subtle taste in some tacos.﻿

comments.text:
What is really funny is when American people come to Mexico and try real 
tacos saying; 'hey! this is not real tacos, real tacos are American style 
tacos', true and sad story. On the other hand, tacos are not Mexican food, 
actually, they are snacks, real Mexican cuisine is rather complex to be 
cooked and so rich in flavour that it is not an easy task to copycat the 
flavour, just like French, Italian, Arabic or any other sort of food from 
other countries. I'm not sure, but in my opinion, American food is quite 
simplistic and therefore not really difficult to cook and get exactly the 
same results than food made in the USA. Not an opinion, a fact I guess.﻿

comments.author: hanubi -_-

comments.text:
"Why are you making our food into... into this?" - Uhhh, because people 
like it. Honestly, this happens with a lot of types of food. You take a 
concept that is traditional and has some measure of popularity and you 
regionalize and slightly (or sometimes drastically) change it to suit the 
local demographic. More than that, it isn't really *your* food at that 
point anymore, it's something built on ideas that originated in one place, 
but that were changed. I know we still call it "Mexican" food, which is 
probably really inaccurate, but I wouldn't think of it that way.﻿

comments.author: Ownage367

comments.text:
Let's be honest comparing Taco Bell to true Mexican (or even properly 
prepared Mexican-American food) is like comparing a quality hamburger to a 
McDonald's burger. You're expecting fast food to hold  up against properly 
prepared food? 

I know hard shelled tacos are essentially non-existent in Mexico, but a 
good Mexican chef could probably create a hard shelled one with authentic, 
quality taste. Using real cheese and quality meats as opposed to the 
plastic and sand that Taco Bell uses might also make these decidedly 
non-authentic food concepts more appealing to Mexican natives.

I remember the video of Chinese people trying Chinese-American foods. The 
consensus seemed to be "it's not Chinese but decent". All I see here is 
Mexican people trying fast food. I'd like to see them give their opinions 
of food from a decent Mexican-American restaurant in the Southwest. That 
would be give us a better understanding of cultural taste differences. 

That said, I loved the Mexican-American food when I lived in Nevada. Living 
back in the Northeast, all I can say is we need to pass a constitutional 
amendment barring white people from working in Mexican kitchens. Even if it 
was Americanized, the food that the Mexican-Americans put out was 
absolutely amazing. Bright, incredible flavors.﻿
